WRITING.TEXT: Maybe they were trying to scare the shit out of someone...

WRITING.TITLE: I used the bathroom at the laundromat and this was all over the walls, ceiling, and door.
Period sex?!?!
WRITING.TEXT: [removed]

"Captain, being held by you isn't quite enough to get me excited."
"IT'S A TRAP!"
This is wonderful! Thank you for all the tips!

WRITING.TITLE: Fun, sexy ways to surprise your dom?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm in a longterm, live-in relationship with my boyfriend. He and I are in a DD/LG relationship, and it's my first real experience in any kind of definite D/S relationship. I feel so comfortable and happy as a sub, but sometimes letting Daddy fuck my face as a special treat gets very...monotonous. I love it, and I'm great at it, but I just wish there were more things I could do to surprise him and serve him. I'd love to be able to keep him guessing. Any advice?
Why do you guys recommend staying away? Are they fake tips to get us busted?
Those games have RFID tags inside the package already. If there's a bathroom, go there and remove it.

Just held it as if I was going to purchase it, shopped around until I got to my blind spot, then ducked to look at stuff on the bottom shelf, quickly detagged it and slid it in my purse while "digging in my purse for my phone". I stood up, strolled around looking at other items, and walked out.
I try my best!

WRITING.TITLE: Another haul: Publix, Urban Outfitters, Ulta, Target, and Joann Fabrics.

WRITING.TEXT: The food aisle. But I mostly just do push outs, so I guess a blind spot doesn't matter that much.
No, I didn't buy anything. I've been lifting at target for over a year and never got caught. It could still happen, but I've learned a lot and I'm much more careful than when I started.
Garden section at Walmart near closing time.

Yes!! Ask for items they don't have if employees bug you. I usually ask where their Kat Von D makeup is. if a palette has a sensor, it's usually an RFID sticker and you can see it on the outside. Just peel it off. Be careful about ditching packages because they'll eventually catch onto you. But I have a big purse, so I just take the de-tagged palettes to my blind spot and I look at items on a low shelf and slide the palettes into my purse.
Ulta LP is regional and is only in certain stores a few times a year. But look out for the manager. Ulta managers usually leave kinda early so I'd advise hitting them later in the day, like after 7:00.

Nah, I have both boxes. I just peeled off the RFID tags. And there is AP for Sephora but AP for Ulta is regional so they are only there a few times a year. Managers are the only people you really have to look out for but they typically get done with their work early in the evening. I usually go to Ulta after 7:00.
I got another palette today. You just have to look out for cameras/employees. I hold them down low so no one can see and slide them into my purse.
I brought my purse in with me, and when I got to a blind spot I just slid them in my bag.
Thank you!
I've heard you can get all kinds of stuff there!
Yeah...I had a pretty good lift at Ulta later last night with no problems, but had to stop myself before I got greedy.
What store was that?

I got this one at Barnes and Noble.
Also Hot Topic.
I stand by this! Better safe than sorry.
Most likely not. The ones at Walmart are decoys.
Definitely take a break. If you're nervous about lifting you're more likely to get caught...Good luck!
Yesss! I love them. I couldn't decide between Poison Ivy and Jessica Jones. But Jessica is my favorite.
Sorry, I was living out of it for two months.
Do it! Take baby steps. Lol.
I realize I worded the title weirdly. This stuff was from Walmart and Target. I went to Ulta about an hour or so ago.

WRITING.TITLE: The Magic of Purses
WRITING.TEXT:
Purses make lifting so much fucking easier than you can imagine. Sometimes I feel like I have a bag like Mary Poppins. No one suspects a thing when a woman goes into a store with a huge, slouchy purse slung over her shoulder. My purse has a crossbody strap that frees up both my hands and makes things even easier. As long as you're confident, you can slip small items into your bag without even being in a blind spot. Just keep walking and looking forward, not down at your hands or up at the ceiling trying to find cameras. I have grown a lot in my lifting skills and one of the best things to do in your blind spot is just take the items and fucking drop them in your purse. You can't even hesitate for a second, and it should be one quick, smooth movement. That's the key to success.
Fuck, I love my purse...
Thank you.
Dear god, no. My asshole isn't that big.

I'll take that as a compliment...most of the larger items I took from Target. I just did a simple push-out with them hidden under my purse. My purse is fucking huge. Then, I got some other items from Walmart...I dropped them in my gigantic purse in a blind spot and then strolled happily to the register and bought a coke. Made friends with the cashier too. Her name was Estrella.
Thank you!!
Nooo, this was all from Walmart and Target. I went to Ulta at like 8:00.
No, I went to Ulta a little while ago. The brushes are AMAZING. And no RFID.
I was very lucky today. I lifted over $500 total, from Walmart, rue21, Old Navy, Ulta, Barnes and Noble, and Target.
The economy these days, am I right?

WRITING.TITLE: My proudest haul yet. Over $200 in makeup, a romper from Old Navy, and a Jessica Jones pop vinyl.

WRITING.TEXT:
I have mad respect for you. You seem very reasonable and like a stand-up, decent human being. The few AP I've encountered (especially at Target) are so fucking rude and act like lifters are animals, even those (like myself) who lift out of necessity.
My question is, what would an announcement over the intercom for LP sound like? Do they do that at Target?
Also, what would you consider the best method for lifting at Target? Using the reusable shopping bags? I've done a few push-outs with food and groceries but I feel like this is a dangerous method since every once in a while I see an APS at the door checking receipts.

WRITING.TITLE: Today's haul! Heading back to Ulta later to get some treats for myself along with things to resell.

WRITING.TEXT: Meh, I just ended up doing a good old-fashioned push out. My tried and true favorite method at this particular store. It's worked for me so far, so I can't complain.

WRITING.TITLE: Best way to do the cereal box trick without looking suspicious?
WRITING.TEXT:
Yes, I know, go to a blind spot. But I'm still worried I'll look sketchy as fuck shoving stuff into a cereal box.
Are you guys sure self checkout will deactivate security tags? I'm probably just being stupid, but I'm paranoid since I've never lifted like this before.
I talk to myself too!

WRITING.TITLE: Weirdest or funniest shit you've ever done/said while high?
WRITING.TEXT:
A few nights ago, I was high off my ass and started taking closeup pictures of my left eye with the flash on, which for some reason was making me laugh really hard. I doubled over and grabbed my stomach and was panicking to my boyfriend that I couldn't stop laughing and asked if I would ever stop before my stomach exploded.
I also asked my boyfriend "Was Justin Timberlake in blink-182? ...fuck, I meant N*SYNC. I want garlic bread."
I've also started laughing, then once I forget why I stop laughing and then immediately start back up again after realizing that I looked so silly. A never ending cycle. Lmao.

The one I go to is small and has one camera...there are 3 employees who are usually busy helping customers and don't address me. I grab items quickly, hold them under my arm and take them to a fitting room near the mall exit. Fitting rooms aren't monitored so I take my items in with some clothes to "try on", take the RFID tags off the makeup, stick them to the back of the mirror so no one can see, and put the makeup in my bag, then hang the clothes up. I left once with two Modern Renaissance palettes (one for me and one to resell), a NARS foundation and concealer, 3 beauty blenders, and the Sweet Peach Palette.

WRITING.TITLE: Do any of you guys have partners who don't lift/don't know you lift?
WRITING.TEXT:
My boyfriend has no idea I lift. He's super against it and would freak if he found out. I wish I could tell him, but he'd be so upset and he'd think I'm crazy. We can't afford groceries and clothes and medicine and shit so I lift for the two of us. I want us both to live comfortably and be taken care of.
Do you guys have a partner who doesn't lift? Or does your partner not know you lift at all? How do you explain all the new stuff to them?
Thanks!
Not at all. I have to get all this shit out of my system. Would vitamins help?
Me too!
Why thank you! ;) lmao.
I love it!
Publix is the shit. I highly recommend it.
After a lift, I always get anxious anytime I see a cop or a cop car...which is terrible because where I live, cops are allowed to take their squad cars home with them.

Ulta is much easier to me. Sephora inside of JC Penney is easier than a standalone store...I've hit the JC Penney one 3 times with not a single problem, but on my second trip to a standalone store near me I got caught. Probably because I got greedy, but oh well.
True!!! I love grocery stores with reusable bags for that very reason. Lmao.
It's cheap and convenient, but it's shit for you. I've noticed a huge difference in my energy and my health since I started eating it regularly.

WRITING.TITLE: I love Publix!
WRITING.TEXT: My boyfriend and I just moved into our first apartment, which sadly exhausted all of our money except for $8.00, but we needed groceries to eat fresh, healthy stuff since I've been extremely sick lately and we've been living off of the dollar menu at McDonald's. We needed to get some Gatorade since I've been puking and dehydrated, so I offered to run to the store...I lifted a 6 pack of Gatorade and some frozen meals, some pasta, fresh fruit, potato chips, and a gallon of milk. I filled a cart and just pushed it out...told my boyfriend that everything was on sale I love Publix.
Yeah, I'm gonna pass. I'll try somewhere else. Haha.
That's okay! No worries, haha. I'm gonna scope things out more before I make a move. More likely than not I won't do anything.
I definitely won't be lifting anything then....lmao.

No, I meant I walk 5 miles during a shift. I'm in retail in a shoe department, and we're not allowed to sit during our shift unless we're on break. We have to go to the back to get shoes for customers and our stockroom has two floors. It's more walking than you'd think.

More items are tagged at Nordstrom Rack - even shoes, which we don't do at my store. From my own experience, Nordstrom Rack employees don't earn commission so they are less eager to approach a customer. I've never seen an employee on the floor in the Nordstrom Rack I go to. Nordstrom Rack is smaller and has almost no shelves which makes it hard to conceal anything.
Thank you! Glad you understand a little better. We're not all bad people. :)

I moved out of my parents' home 4 months ago because I was being abused severely, both physically and emotionally. When I left, I was homeless and crashed on several couches until I could finally afford an apartment (I moved in two days ago.) I shoplift groceries and necessities, and sometimes more expensive things to sell for money.
Just post one to the group! I'm sure everyone will be impressed.
Yay! I'm happy for you! And no problem, I enjoyed giving the advice, haha. Lemme see a picture!
I look forward to hearing about it! And that would be fantastic. Lol. Good luck, guys.

No problem! I'm glad she's enjoying these too. Lol. Sometimes they'll just be RFID tags you can just peel off but now they also have these weird tags that beep in low light or in response to any motion. Watch out for those. They're easy to spot though.

No problem!
Eyeshadow palettes usually have sensors. So does perfume. Any contour palettes or glow kits by Anastasia Beverly Hills will be tagged, so will any Naked palettes or the Sweet Peach eyeshadow palette from Too Faced. Basically the most popular items are the ones they tag.
My favorite items to lift from Ulta are foundation, rollerball perfumes (some of these are tagged though), eyebrow pencils, lipstick, mascara, and highlighter.

Sure! At my training, we met our loss prevention manager at the store. He's very friendly once you get to know him but was of course trying to scare the shit out of us. To me, Nordstrom is more focused on internal theft than anything. We have a specific door that only employees can use, and everyone has a unique code to get in. If you try to hold the door open for someone, an alarm will go off. The cameras are state of the art PTZ cameras and they're all over the store. We have no shelves and everything is very open, so no blind spots.
We learned some basic LP training when I was hired, but the main thing they told us was that we're not allowed to apprehend even if we see someone put something in their bag. Because it "offends the customer". But we have a special key on our computer to page LP to come to our area. There is always someone watching cameras and they have several plainclothes. When we need LP, we page "Clay Morgan" to come to whatever department needs help.
One of the managers who trained us said that "the best deterrent to theft is great customer service!" Pffffft. That's actually company policy. It was in our handbook.
We mostly get return fraud but like any other store people will conceal shit in their bags and go. LP has their own office where they detain lifters and cuff them. They take LP very seriously and will directly contact the police.
Cameras can see everything from the color of your eyes to the time on your fucking watch. They're the same cameras that are used in casinos.
I'm SO tempted to lift something from our store (because there's no way in hell I could afford anything there), but I would recommend not fucking with Nordstrom.

No problem! I'm flattered that you asked me. Lol.
All of the employees wear all black. At most Ultas, only the employees at the cash wrap have headsets, along with the store manager. Small items (lipsticks, eyebrow pencils, blushes, etc.) are easy to grab and conceal and usually aren't tagged. Mainly be on the lookout for RFIDs (and sometimes they hide sensors in packaging...be careful) If employees try to approach you, ask where you can find an item that they don't have (like Hourglass products, Kat Von D products, or Beauty Blenders). This will usually deter them. There's a few good blind spots, especially in the aisles where the drugstore makeup is or where the drugstore skin care products are. Just be aware of employees, nosy customers, cameras, and mirrors. Best tactic is to crouch down and look at "items on the bottom shelf" and peel off sensors, and conceal your haul in your bag.
Good to know! Thanks for the awesome reply.
I've lifted from there. They usually do receipt checks, but if you go late at night it's a lot easier. Staff will watch you pretty closely but I walked out once with a brand-new pair of $150 Nikes.
Pawnee: First in friendship, fourth in obesity.
Very true! Plus a lot of teenagers shop there and teenagers are always looked out for by LP. But the items aren't very expensive so maybe that's got something to do with it
Lol, I get it. I'm new here too. But thanks for looking out for me. Don't be a stranger!

Totally agree with everything you had to say here. I also find it serendipitous that the majority of folks I've met in this community are genuinely good people. Lifting doesn't make someone a bad person. People with no concern for others and with huge egos (i.e. the Walton siblings) are the real bad people in this world.
I appreciate your kind words, man. Be safe and keep doing what you're doing. You're a really good person and I wish you the best.
I've never seen/heard of LP at Forever 21. That's really interesting! Anytime I've lifted there it's been pretty easy.

Thank you! I'm so excited! Lifting has played a significant role in me being able to finally afford a place. Once I started getting good, I'd lift more expensive things (especially makeup) and sell them to save up some cash or for lunch money. I also still lift groceries (especially at places with reusable bags) because no one can live off of McDonalds and soda, and healthy food is expensive as fuck.
I enjoy lifting and I'm proud of myself when I pull off tricky lifts, but someday I'd like to be secure enough to not have to steal. Well...maybe I will every once in a while. Lol.

Thanks, I appreciate it! Adulting is hard as fuck but it's better than what my parents put me through. I'm moving into my first apartment tomorrow so I'm officially Not Homeless! But Publix is fantastic.

When I moved out of my parents' house earlier this year to get away from the abuse, I used to go get a sandwich with fresh meat and lots of veggies and a drink at the deli, or hot soup for dinner. It was nice to have a substantial, fresh, healthy meal for free instead of spending a dollar on a McChicken every day.
Honestly, I think publix kind of assumes the best in people. I sometimes feel a tiny bit bad lifting from them, because everyone there is so genuinely friendly and helpful.
But fuck yeah. Publix is a goldmine.
TRUUUUUU
No problem! If you ever need anymore advice let me know.
That could work, but be careful where you put the spider wrap. Best bet is to make sure no one else is in the bathroom and then put it in one of the ceiling tiles
I wouldn't ditch the item in the bathroom because when they look at footage they'll know it was you, unless you had it concealed first.

Nice review, also super accurate...I work at a Nordstrom and LP is SUPER tight. They don't fuck around.
We have a button on the register that pages LP to our area instantly. There's quite a few plainclothes, tons of PTZ cameras, no shelves, and we have a code name for LP so over the intercom you'll hear "(Codename) to (insert department here)"
Be careful.
No it's totally okay!!! lol I get it!
Well it's just shoes and those are above an open entryway, so no one's getting naked. Lol
I'm not a fan of edibles.

At my school, they had these gross, plastic wrapped brownies that were 50 cents in the lunch line. I had a friend who had just gotten into smoking and was always bragging about it and annoying the fuck out of everyone. So one day, I unwrapped a brownie from the lunch line and gave it to him, telling him it was a pot brownie. He believed me, and he made a big show telling everyone he was "so fucking high (he) didn't remember where he was, LOL". Made himself look like an ass in front of everyone.

I remember hearing that about fitting rooms, but these are above the entrance to our stock room. I work in the shoe department of a high end department store so this is just where we keep any items that aren't on display (other sizes, colors, out of season styles, etc.) idk. My store is pretty serious about internal theft
I'm gonna be careful anyway, lmao
No way! That's interesting. Good to know!
That makes sense.

Maybe I'll ask a manager. I've never seen a camera like that in my life, and there's like 5 of them right next to each other. Plus they're at the entrance to the stock room and I don't think anyone would do anything suspicious there...

Yeah, I kinda doubt they're cameras because there's like 5 of them right next to each other and they're all at the entrance to the stock room. I'd think if someone was gonna lift from the stock room, they wouldn't do it in the entrance. Lmao.

WRITING.TITLE: I've seen a few requests for this...
WRITING.TEXT:
So this isn't perfect, but I recently made a post detailing my experiences at stores and my advice as far as risk level goes, and I saw a few commenters who wanted to make a master list of personal experiences with stores.
Here's my idea: comment with your experiences below and rate each store's risk level (in your opinion) on a scale of 1-5. (One being the lowest, 5 being the highest) Once I get an ample amount of responses, I'll compile a master list and average the risk rating for each store, and add on a short description of general comments.
Let me know what you guys think of this idea/format and add on your experiences with different stores and a 1-5 risk level.
Happy lifting!
I definitely think everyone's personal experiences would be interesting too, to assess a general risk level and get a better idea of what everyone else has to say.
I think that's a good idea too. I'd definitely be interested in contributing.

WRITING.TITLE: Several of these are above our stock room in the store I work at. Do you think they're cameras?

WRITING.TEXT:
Yeah, I realize that store layouts vary. These were just my personal experiences (partly because I wanted to sit down and make a solid list of every place I've lifted from, LOL) and because I hoped maybe you guys could take something from it. I know lifting is different for everyone but I just figured I'd give you all my 2 cents. Definitely scope the place out, and pay attention to the atmosphere. If you get a bad vibe, LEAVE.
Also, that is a fair point about the mesh shopping bags, but I have a fairly large purse and that concealed the shopping bag easily.
Yes!! I almost forgot I've lifted here. Had to get a bag of dog food. Lol.

WRITING.TITLE: My Lifting Experiences/Advice
WRITING.TEXT:
This is a list of all the stores I've lifted from and MY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE in case it can be of use to anyone. I'm not claiming these circumstances are the same at every single store, so if you take my advice, proceed with caution.
Target - first store I started lifting at. Started stealing small things, then did several push-outs. They have reusable bags now which makes it easy. My best trick was to start heading toward the exit through the dollar spot and look at items there, then when employees and customers are gone, confidently head to the exit.
Walmart - SO MANY BLIND SPOTS. Customers are nosy though. Not many items are tagged and some of the "sensors" on their jewelry are decoys.
CVS - fairly easy to lift from. Employees don't care. Plenty of blind spots. But sometimes they hide the sensors on their products really well (especially cosmetics) and you have to be careful. Best bet is to head to the bathroom and remove packaging, then stash it in a ceiling tile. Use the hand dryer to mask any noises the packaging makes. Be careful because checkout lines are near the exit, so employees hang out there...not many blind spots.
Publix - back when I was practically homeless, I used to go to their deli and order sandwiches, make myself a drink, and walk out. Good, easy way to get a healthy and substantial meal. They don't ring you up at the deli so you can just walk out.
Ulta - several blind spots (i.e. drugstore makeup and hair care or skincare) come late in the day, when the manager is gone, and when there are few employees and they all want to go home. They won't address you. Be careful of sneaky RFID tags. Some of their products are tagged with these weird, light-sensing things that SUCK. easy to conceal small items. Best tactic for me is to go to an aisle with few cameras and no customers and to crouch down to "look at items on the bottom shelf" and then stuff items in my purse. Park away from the store because they WILL get your license plate number.
Sephora - BEWARE. This is the one store I've ever been busted in, and I've been lifting for over a year. Employees are very condescending and they will watch you like a hawk if you don't have a certain "look". They follow you around the store and every employee has a walkie/headset. Nothing is tagged, so if you're really good, go right ahead, especially if they're busy. I've gotten away once with a pretty decent haul. Sephora inside of JC Penney is a fucking cake walk. Items are tagged but the towers are at the exits to the entire store. There's normally only one or two employees. Stupidly enough, popular items (at the store in my area) are stocked around the perimeter which makes it sooo easy to just grab them under your arm and walk away. Head to a fitting room (which are totally unattended by the way) and peel off the RFID tags. I stick them to the back of the mirror so no one will see.
Barnes and Noble - fairly easy, but employees are somewhat hard to spot. My number one tactic is to grab some books I like, wander around the store "shopping" and then casually head over to the Starbucks. I chill at a table near the exit (yes, there is an exit in the caf and it makes things gloriously easy) and read, then leave.
Sally Beauty Supply - this one is moderately difficult. There's like one camera in the store and it's a small store with very hands-on employees, but you're golden if you come in when they're super busy or late at night when no one wants to help any customers. Nothing is tagged and the shelves are super tall!
Victoria's Secret - this one can be difficult if a lot of people are working because they will customer service the shit out of you. Try to go late at night. Make sure you can spot all of the employees. The VS I go to has a bathroom and multiple exits, which is a life saver. The little panty drawers make your job easier because you can crouch down to "look in the bottom drawer" while concealing goodies. (I actually visited there today)
Forever 21 - most jewelry is not tagged. Occasionally a random item will not be tagged. If they have those mesh shopping bags, look for one that doesn't have a sensor on it (this doesn't take long). Casually fill it up with items to "purchase" and then stroll the fuck out while the cashiers are busy with other customers.
Old Navy - at the store near me, I have seen an employee actually on the floor ONCE. Fitting rooms are usually NOT monitored (especially early in the morning) and a good bit of their items are not tagged. Just take a few items to the dressing room (some you want and some you don't want. They won't count them), stuff the ones you want in your bag, and leave the ones you don't. The stores are usually super busy with very little staff. Have fun!
Famous footwear - easy if you're experienced. Clearance shelves are super high up and easy to conceal in. Staff do not help you much unless you approach them first. Little to no cameras.
Ross - easy to pocket small items (journals, makeup, trinkets, etc.) but most of their shit is tagged. They count items going into fitting rooms. Cash wrap "blocks" the exit.
JoAnn - SUPER EASY. I've done a few push-outs here. A friend of mine just stuck a $300 sewing machine in a cart and walked out, no questions asked. Very few employees, little to no cameras, and tall shelves. Just be cautious around the sewing department/fabrics.
DSW - fairly easy. Not many employees but lots of customers. NO CAMERAS in the clearance section. Only purses/glasses are tagged. Just act confident.
Torrid - I used to work here and it's so easy. They don't chase or apprehend (don't want to "offend" the customer). There are usually 1-3 employees working at a time. No cameras, no LP. They don't count items going into fitting rooms, but almost all items are tagged.
Best Buy - VERY RISKY. Stick to small items and act like you're just browsing. Act like you're not doing anything wrong, and head to the bathroom as long as no employees are nearby (they're allowed to follow you), then remove the packaging because their sensors are sneaky and stash it in a ceiling tile.
Staples - super easy. Outdated cameras, few employees. Shelves are extremely high and can conceal you easily. Toys R Us - a fucking cake walk. It's easy to get away from employees because the store is so huge. Quite a few cameras, though. But if you go later at night there's very few employees at the cash wrap so you can just walk out.
Victoria's Secret Pink - employees are somewhat pushy, put it's pretty simple when they're busy. All clothing is tagged but perfumes, lotions etc. are a buffet.
Urban Outfitters - somewhat difficult because the store layout is fairly open, but employees generally don't give a shit and lounge around at the cash wrap talking. They aren't consistent with tagging items and most of the time won't approach you at all.
MAC Cosmetics - be VERY careful. I wouldn't recommend going here just because you won't get much out of it. I stole a sample once but that was all I could get away with. Employees are similar to the ones at Sephora, very rude and judgmental and will single customers out. Their products are stored in drawers that they flip out if you touch AT ALL. Boo.
Disney Store - easy but I stole there once and felt like a terrible person. They aren't allowed to chase or apprehend and very little is tagged.
JC Penney - easy late at night. There are almost no employees in sight and very little is tagged. I grabbed two dresses and walked out without seeing anyone.
Books a Million - nothing is tagged. Few if any employees on the floor.
Nordstrom ****I've never lifted here but I work here and wanted to give you guys a warning. VERY IMPORTANT. I wouldn't recommend lifting here...we are all trained in basic LP, we have the same cameras as casinos (PTZ and "can go so far as to read your phone screen" per my LPM) and our registers have buttons to page LP. There is a code name for LP (not sure if I should mention it) and we have plainclothes LP too. They don't fuck around.
Whoops...let me fix it and repost.
I have a shirt that looks like a cheesy postcard and says "Jonestown" with the Kool-Aid Man on it, also a "Jurassic Parks and Rec" shirt with Chris Pratt on it.

There's so many blind spots in the Ulta where I visit, and the workers are normally too apathetic to even address people when they're in the store.
Also, there's a Sephora inside of JC Penney and it's like a fucking buffet. You just grab shit and conceal it, then head to one of the dressing rooms (which are never monitored, btw) and stash the trash in the ceiling. Easy as pie.

I've done several push-outs at Target for over a year and have never been caught. I was apprehended once but I was let go immediately. Ulta is somewhat easy if you know what to take. They have these new weird sensors now with a light sensor, so that if you palm them or stick them in a bag they beep. It's pretty easy to find blind spots at Ulta and I've never even been approached by staff. I know what hours are the best to lift based on who's working.
I just joined the group. Haven't done much looking around.

WRITING.TITLE: a quick question
WRITING.TEXT:
Where do you buy detachers? And what is an S3/how do I get one? I've been shoplifting a little over a year and have limited myself to items with no tags. Gets tricky because I really need nice clothes for my job but I don't have much luck when all I can get is stuff someone forgot to stick a tag on...
Also, what are your best tips for lifting clothes/makeup?
I definitely know that's true! I've never been charged/arrested etc. but anytime I feel like something's off I'll just ditch the stuff in an empty aisle and head out.
Yeah, I need to use different techniques...I've been apprehended by an LP agent before but I got out of it. Needless to say I don't go there anymore. Lol

WRITING.TITLE: i thought i was the only one!
WRITING.TEXT:
Glad to see such an awesome community of people. I've hidden my lifting from my boyfriend and friends and family...although I did get a close friend to start. Lol.
I'm not exactly a rookie. I've been lifting for a little over a year now, but my techniques aren't great.
They work, so I guess that's alright, but I've been somewhat sloppy and I worry that I could get caught. I came to this community to meet my fellow lifters and learn some tricks of the trade!
My favorite places to lift from are Target, Walmart, Ulta, and Old Navy. Comment your favorite stores below!
